Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
"The SMaRT Scholars for Success" program at Northampton Community College is increasing the number of low-income, academically talented women and minorities in multiple STEM programs by implementing best practices for enhancing the recruitment, retention, and successful transfer or employment of students underrepresented in STEM. The program is working to address the financial, academic, and emotional barriers that can prove formidable for all students and often affect traditionally underrepresented students most significantly. Scholars are supported as a "Community of Learners" through participation in a summer retreat, learning circles by discipline, common courses, and other cohort building activities. A high level of academic support is provided by a Student Success Specialist, tutors, career advisors, faculty and industrial mentors, experiential learning opportunities and workshops to develop leadership and soft skills.

"SMaRT Scholars for Success" provides a model for increasing the recruitment, retention, and success rate of students underrepresented in STEM disciplines. Most of the strategies used in this project can be implemented at modest cost to a comparable institution. With community colleges accounting for 46% of the nation's undergraduates and over half of all minorities in higher education, the project offers the opportunity for broad impact on the STEM pipeline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SMaRT Scholars for Success Outcomes

The Science Mathematics and Related Technologies (SMaRT) Scholars for Success program was a $600,000 NSF-funded S-STEM grant at Northampton Community College (NCC) in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania. The goal of the project was to learn how to recruit more women and minorities, who are underrepresented in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) programs and careers and how to keep them in a STEM field. Over the six years of the grant we were able to recruit 129 scholars with almost two-thirds of them women or minorities, a large increase over typical representations in STEM programs. Almost 95% of the scholars stayed in a STEM program during the life of the grant.

One of our objectives was to recruit a group of scholars that was 75% women and minorities. We were able to do this with the last two groups. To accomplish this we used numerous techniques. We advertised on the college website, created a project website and a Facebook page, created flyers and posters, and disseminated information about the program to non-profits that dealt with the targeted groups. The Admissions Office distributed information about the program to high school and technical school counselors. Letters about the program were sent to high school math and science teachers and distributed at science fairs. Current scholars and college STEM faculty were also used in the recruiting effort. Flyers were also distributed to new students during summer orientation sessions.

 

A second objective was to retain students in STEM programs. The program addressed the financial, academic, and emotional barriers that have resulted in many STEM majors, especially underrepresented students, leaving STEM in the past. The program used summer retreats, enrolling scholars in common sections of key courses, monthly seminars, field trips, conferences, and speakers to create a community of learners with each group of scholars. The program provided a high level of academic support for scholars, including a Student Success Specialist, tutors, career advisors, faculty and industry mentors, experiential learning opportunities and workshops to develop leadership and soft skills. As noted above the project kept scholars in the STEM pipeline with only a few exceptions. During the grant period 7% of NCC students graduated within 2 years. The graduation rate within 2 years for SMaRT Scholars was 46.4%. The program collaborated with colleges and businesses to provide opportunities for job shadowing, internships, and undergraduate research. For example, 35 students participated in programs at Lehigh University that allowed them to either enroll (paying NCC tuition) in a biology course that gave them undergraduate research experience or to get a paid research position either in the summer or during an academic semester.

The third objective was to assist scholars to transfer into a STEM program at a 4-year college or obtain employment in a STEM field. The Student Success Specialist helped them choose courses that would transfer to their intended 4-year college, helped them create resumes, and practice for interviews. The program paid for scholars to attend an etiquette luncheon that prepared them for interviews in restaurants. Transfer and Career counselors made presentations to the scholars and taught them how to use online tools to help them in the transfer process or in finding employment. Most graduates transferred after graduation, with only 14% obtaining employment. Only one of these obtained employment in a non-STEM field and that was by choice. We could not obtain information on four graduates. Where we had information only one transferred to a non-STEM major.

The project had an impact at the College and our successes have been disseminated regionally and nationally. At NCC a number of the activities of the grant have been institutionalized. But the real impact of the program was on the scholars. The impact on one scholar illustrates this impact. Mark is a black male and Computer Science major. At the start of the two-day retreat, the first time the scholars met each other, Mark stayed in a corner and did not interact with the other scholars. He was extremely shy, was not sure he belonged, and lacked some social skills. By the end of the two days he knew the names of all the other scholars and was joking with those he learned to know best. He was able to tell the scholars about himself and talk about his goals. The next summer, after listening to a presentation by a Lehigh University professor at a seminar, he applied for and received a paid summer research position. The experience was transforming for him. He was offered and acceptable a paid part-time position for the fall. He now is comfortable giving talks to groups and was the co-author of two research papers. He transferred to Lehigh and continues his research there.
